prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: 13CO and C18O J=1-0 transitions in band 3 are reasonable tracers of the dense gas filaments in BRCs and we will observe this area also in dust continuum to combine with akari data and probe dust properities. Urquhart et al.2006 observed around this area centered on the cometary head of this cloud with Mopra telescope in CO emission and they defined the core size as the FWMH of 13CO intensity maps: ~41". Therefore our observation area is defined to cover the core size. And we observed SFO82 before in CO emission with NANTEN2 and Mopra telescopes, and the intensity of C18O (J=1--0) emission is typically 2.5 K. So the desired sensitivity is ~0.5K. Finally, 2" angular resolution is needed to decompose into some clumps since the observation results for SFO82 showed there are five clumps having ~1.0 pc length over the cometary head(~6pc), which suggests a clump size is expected to be about one-sixth of the cometary head of a BRC size, and this size corresponds to ~10" at a few kpc.

this area is observed with Spitzer Space Telescope at 24um. The infrared sources are located around the top of the cometary head of this cloud (75" x 75"), and this is our observation area with ALMA. The angular resolution and desired sensitivity are needed to be 2" and ~0.5 K respectively in the same reason to other sources.

Urqhart et al.2006 observed around this area centered on the cometary head of this cloud with Mopra telescope in CO emission and they defined the core size as the FWMH of 13CO intensity maps: ~64". Therefore our observation area is defined to cover the core size. The angular resolution and desired sensitivity are needed to be 2" and ~0.5 K respectively in the same reason to other sources.

Morgan et al.2008 observed around this area to cover the whole are of BRCs using SCUBA on the James Clerk Maxwell telescope(JCMT) in 450um and 850um and they defined the core size as a contour of sub millimetre emission at or above the 3 sigma level and equal to or grater than the size of the FWMH of the JCMT beam. Therefore our observation area is defined to cover the core size: ~80"x160”. And the angular resolution and desired sensitivity are needed to be 2" and ~0.5 K respectively in the same reason to other sources.

Morgan et al.2008 observed around this area to cover the whole are of BRCs using SCUBA on the James Clerk Maxwell telescope(JCMT) in 450 and 850um and they defined the core size as a contour of sub millimetre emission at or above the 3 sigma level and equal to or grater than the size of the FWMH of the JCMT beam. Therefore our observation area is defined to cover the core size: ~95"x100”. And the angular resolution and desired sensitivity are needed to be 2" and ~0.5 K respectively in the same reason to other sources.

This area has not been observed so far and this source is classified as type B in SFO catalog. SFO 82 is also classified as type B and its length of filament is almost consistent with the one of BRC and its width is about one-third of one of the BRC. Therefore this area (length x width/3) is the observation area, which is expected to be filamentary component. The angular resolution and desired sensitivity are needed to be 2 aresec and ~0.5 K respectively in the same reason to other sources.

This area is observed with Spitzer Space Telescope at 24um. The infrared sources are located around the top of the cometary head of this cloud (80" x 90"), and this is our observation area with ALMA. The angular resolution and desired sensitivity are needed to be 2 are sec and ~0.5 K respectively in the same reason to other sources.

This area has not been observed so far. Therefore we define observation area of SFO54 with ALMA taking into account its size and type of SFO catalog. SFO54 is type A and its core component is expected to be the top of the cometary head of this cloud from the theoretical work of Bisbas et al. 2011. Their simulation results indicate that the UV radiation forms a filamentary dense gas on side of the exciting stars. Therefore the observation area size is defined to cover the top of the cometary head of this cloud. And the angular resolution and desired sensitivity are needed to be 2 are sec and ~0.5 K respectively in the same reason to other sources.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The energetic mass-compression by UV photons of O stars is one of the most promising triggers of high-mass star formation and is a crucial step in the galactic evolution. Bright rimmed clouds (BRCs) embedded in HII regions are one of the most promising objects where we may observe the detailed physics of such triggering thanks to their closeness at 1-4 kpc. Recent observational studies suggest that the triggering forms a filamentary dense gas pointing toward the exciting stars in the largest BRC, SFO82. Such formation of a dense filament is consistent with numerical simulations of BRCs by Bisbas et al. (2011). The width and mass density of the filament is critical in star formation since the fragmentation and collapse of the filament will determine the mass of the forming stars. In order to explore the triggering in BRCs we here propose to survey 9 typical BRCs with ALMA aiming at establishing the filament formation and star formation therein. This will allow us to test if the formation of filaments is a common feature in BRCs, and will open a unique possibility to quantify the stars formed in BRCs with the help of theoretical analyses of fragmentation of filamentary clouds.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Graduate School of Science, Nagoya University
